issues.title: ENH: Optional preservation of Sparse columns in Parquet/Feather via Arrow metadata
issues.body:
### Summary
Add an opt-in flag to preserve `SparseDtype` on Parquet/Feather roundtrip by storing minimal dtype metadata in Arrow schema and reconstructing on read. No behavior change by default.
### API
- Write: `DataFrame.to_parquet(..., preserve_sparse=False)`, `DataFrame.to_feather(..., preserve_sparse=False)`
- Read: `read_parquet(..., preserve_sparse=False)`, `read_feather(..., preserve_sparse=False)`
- Alternative name for feedback: `preserve_extension_arrays`.
### Behavior
- Default (`False`): current behavior unchanged (dense on read).
- When `True`: write Arrow field metadata (subtype, fill_value); read reconstructs `SparseArray(SparseDtype)`.
### Implementation sketch
- Writer: detect `SparseDtype` columns, attach schema field metadata (e.g., `b"pandas.sparse.dtype"`, `b"pandas.sparse.version"`), keep physical encoding compatible.
- Reader: if `preserve_sparse=True` and metadata present, rebuild sparse columns from dense values + recorded `fill_value`/subtype.
### Tests
- Parquet and Feather roundtrip.
- Subtypes: int64/float64/boolean; various `fill_value`s (0, 0.0, False, NaN).
- Mixed frames (sparse + dense).
- Verify off-by-default behavior.
### Notes
- Scopes strictly to I/O compatibility (acknowledges #56518 discussion).
- Backward compatible and opt-in.
- Namespaced metadata (e.g., `pandas.sparse.*`).
### Request for feedback
- API flag name (`preserve_sparse` vs generalized).
- Metadata keys/placement and interop concerns.

issues.title: BUG: String categories are not quoted as expected

labels.name: Output-Formatting
labels.description: __repr__ of pandas objects, to_string

labels.name: Categorical
labels.description: Categorical Data Type

issues.body:
### Pandas version checks

- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [main branch](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas) of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
import pandas as pd
s = pd.Series(["apple", "banana", "cherry", "cherry"], dtype="string")
cat = pd.Categorical(s)
print(cat)
# Expected: Categories (3, string): ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
# Output: Categories (3, string): [apple, banana, cherry]
```

### Issue Description

When Categorical receives a pandas Series with dtype of “string”, representation of string elements in the list of unique categories will not include quotes. During my search against existing Issues, I think this relates to Issues #61890. The proposed fix in PR #61891 only checks dtype against “str”. Therefore, it still fails to check pandas Series with dtype of “string”. This PR fixes this problem by adding a check against “string”, like this:

```
- if self.categories.dtype == "str":
+ if self.categories.dtype == "str" or self.categories.dtype == "string":
```

If this fix is good to you, I can open a PR for your review. 

### Expected Behavior

String categories are expected to be quoted, but the current output is not.

Expected: Categories (3, string): ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
Output: Categories (3, string): [apple, banana, cherry]

issues.title: ENH: Standardize calculation of Pearson correlation

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issue that has not been reviewed by a pandas team member

issues.body:
### Feature Type

- [ ] Adding new functionality to pandas

- [x] Changing existing functionality in pandas

- [ ] Removing existing functionality in pandas


### Problem Description

The various methods for calculating the Pearson correlation between DataFrame columns or between Series have distinct implementations.

[`Series.corr`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/series.py#L2606) calls [`nanops.nancorr`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/nanops.py#L1620), which in turn just drops NaNs pairwise then calls `np.corrcoef`; [`DataFrame.corr`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/series.py#L2606) calls [`_libs/algos.nancorr`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/_libs/algos.pyx#L341), which uses a custom Cython implementation; finally [`DataFrame.corrwith`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/frame.py#L11874) has yet another implementation, this time in Python, but not using numpy.

Is there a reason for these different approaches? If no, wouldn't it make more sense to use a consistent approach in each?

### Feature Description

Standardize which approach is used. Based on how often pandas methods end up calling numpy methods under the hood, it seems sensible to change everything to use [`nanops.nancorr`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/nanops.py#L1620).

### Alternative Solutions

If the Cython implementation in `_lib/algos` is notably faster than `np.corrcoef`, it could make sense to prefer that approach. 

### Additional Context

I have not checked how `corr` is implemented in `GroupBy` or `Window`, but even with these three methods I've mentioned it seems weird to be so inconsistent. I also haven't fully checked if this issue is present for other correlation methods (Kendall and Spearman), but at least [`DataFrame.corrwith`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/main/pandas/core/frame.py#L11874) seems to defer to `nanops`.

All three methods should and do seem to produce the same result, so this is probably low-priority. It is more of an issue from a design and maintenance perspective.

issues.title: BUG: pd.json_normalize has inconsistent validation for non-string keys - accepts integers in some parameter combinations but rejects in others

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issue that has not been reviewed by a pandas team member

issues.body:
### Pandas version checks

- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [main branch](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas) of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
import pandas as pd
data = [{"a": 1, 12: "meta_value", "nested": [{"b": 2}]}]
# This works - integer as meta  
pd.json_normalize(data, meta=[12])
# But this fails - integer as meta (with record_path)
pd.json_normalize(data, record_path=["nested"], meta=[12])
```

### Issue Description

pd.json_normalize exhibits inconsistent behavior when using integer keys in the meta parameter:
meta=[12] (without record_path) - WORKS
 record_path=["nested"], meta=[12] - FAILS with TypeError: sequence item 0: expected str instance, int found

### Expected Behavior

This should either be consistently supported or consistently rejected.

### Installed Versions

Replace this line with the output of pd.show_versions()

issues.title: BUG: ExcelFile.parse sets sheet.max_row and sheet.max_column to None

labels.name: IO Excel
labels.description: read_excel, to_excel

issues.body:
### Pandas version checks

- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [ ] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [main branch](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas) of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
# /// script
# dependencies = [
#     "openpyxl",
#     "pandas",
# ]
# ///
import pandas as pd

# Assuming "some_file.xlsx" exists and contains a sheet "Sheet1" with
# some data, for example cell A1="A Header" and cell A2=1234

with pd.ExcelFile("some_file.xlsx") as excel_file:
    ws = excel_file.book["Sheet1"]

    dim_before = (ws.max_row, ws.max_column)
    print(f"Dimensions of Sheet1: {dim_before=}")

    df = excel_file.parse(sheet_name=ws.title)

    dim_after = (ws.max_row, ws.max_column)

    print(f"Dimensions of Sheet1: {dim_after=}")

assert dim_before == dim_after  # assert fails!

# Expect same values
# But we get dim_before=(2, 1) or whatever is in the file
# and dim_after=(None, None) - unexpectedly dimensions are now None
```

### Issue Description

When using Pandas to read tables from Excel worksheets, the `parse` function messes with the internal dimension variables - it sets max_row and max_column to None.

This is caused by `pandas/io/excel/_openpyxl.py` lines 610 + 611 (the last 2 in the following snippet):
```
    def get_sheet_data(
        self, sheet, file_rows_needed: int | None = None
    ) -> list[list[Scalar]]:
        if self.book.read_only:
            sheet.reset_dimensions()
```
The `reset_dimensions` call resets the values.

Why is this call done, is it necessary? On read-only sheets only?! Can those two lines be removed? Unfortunately there is no comment as to why they are needed. Removing them fixes the issue for me - but would that break otherwise? In any case, I do not expect a "read" operation to change max_row and max_column.

The problem is that I need to read multiple tables from different sheets. So I usually first try to find the position of the tables in the file using openpyxl code on the excel_file.book, then I read the table using excel_file.parse with corresponding parameters (in particular skiprows and skipfooter) And afterwards I still read more stuff from the same sheet. [Excel files from customers can be a big PITA, customers like to put multiple tables one one sheet or add hidden sheets, hidden rows&cols - that would almost be a feature request: read_excel(..., read_hidden_cols=False)]

It came as a surprise that the dimensions are lost after reading.

This is an issue for openpyxl / xlsx files only: when reading an old-style xls file with xlrd instead, the sheet dimension can be found via `book.sheet_by_name("Sheet1").nrows` and `ncols` - and they do not change after reading.


### Expected Behavior

Dimensions should be left alone.

### Installed Versions

Limited to relevant parts

<details>
INSTALLED VERSIONS
------------------
python                : 3.12.3
pandas                : 2.3.3
openpyxl              : 3.1.5
</details>

issues.title: BUG: Inconsistency between `Series[float].__rfloordiv__([timedelta])` and `rfloordiv` and further

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issue that has not been reviewed by a pandas team member

issues.body:
### Pandas version checks

- [x] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [x] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [main branch](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/dev/getting_started/install.html#installing-the-development-version-of-pandas) of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
from datetime import timedelta

import pandas as pd


lis = [timedelta(seconds=1)]
ser = pd.Series([1.0])

ser.rfloordiv(lis)  # works, giving Series[Timedelta]
# lis // ser  # TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for //: 'datetime.timedelta' and 'float'

ser.rmod(lis)  # works, giving Series[Timedelta]
# lis % ser  # TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for %: 'datetime.timedelta' and 'float'

# ser.rdivmod(lis)  # AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute '_name'
# divmod(lis, ser)  # TypeError: ufunc 'divmod' not supported for the input types, and the inputs could not be safely coerced to any supported types according to the casting rule ''safe''
```

### Issue Description

The behavirours of 
- `Series([float])__rfloordiv__([timedelta])` and `rfloordiv`
- `__rmod__` and `rmod`
- `__rdivmod__` and `rdivmod`

are different. This is found in pandas-dev/pandas-stubs#1452.

### Expected Behavior

All should work. It is okay to get `Series[object]` as the result.

### Installed Versions

issues.title: BUG: Memory leak in numpy.dot when using large float128 arrays in loop
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

When repeatedly calling numpy.dot() inside a loop with large arrays of float128 dtype, memory usage increases continuously and is never released, even after deleting the arrays.

This behavior suggests a possible memory leak in the low-level BLAS implementation for extended precision types.
The same code works fine with float64.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
import numpy as np

for i in range(10000):
    a = np.random.rand(1000, 1000).astype(np.float128)
    b = np.dot(a, a)
    del a, b  # Explicit deletion does not stop memory growth
```

### Error message:

```shell
No error message is displayed — the issue is an abnormal memory growth over time.

Monitoring with Windows Task Manager or top shows the process consuming several GB of memory after a few minutes.
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

NumPy version: 2.0.2
Python version: 3.12.12

### Runtime Environment:

BLAS info: Intel(R) MKL 2023.2.1  
LAPACK info: Intel(R) MKL 2023.2.1  
CPU info: AMD Ryzen 7 5800H  


### Context for the issue:

I encountered this problem while running a Monte Carlo simulation where thousands of matrix multiplications are performed using extended precision (float128).

Over time, the memory usage grows linearly, which causes the system to slow down and eventually crash.

This prevents long-running scientific computations that require float128 precision from completing successfully.

issues.title: Unchecked memory allocations
issues.body:
In almost all cases, if a memory allocation in our C & C++ code fails, the failure is handled so that eventually a `MemoryError` exception is raised by Python. I think that is a general rule that we apply to all low-level code: failure to allocate memory should ultimately result in a Python exception and not crash the interpreter.

Here are a few places where we don't check for a memory allocation failure:

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/dtype_transfer.c#L171-L173

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/stringdtype/casts.cpp#L856-L861

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/stringdtype/casts.cpp#L1117-L1118

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1121

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1243

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1458

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/umath/stringdtype_ufuncs.cpp#L1577

The following uses of `std::unordered_set` in `unique.cpp` can throw an exception if an allocation fails, which will crash Python:

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/unique.cpp#L212-L214

* https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/f39abd4ffbca44f01eec353115ffd2d7ad296fb2/numpy/_core/src/multiarray/unique.cpp#L220

(This was not an exhaustive search.)

issues.title: TYP: numpy allows a datetime array to be divided by another array
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

If a numpy array has a datetime type, and is divided by another array, typecheckers are not picking that up as wrong.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
from typing import reveal_type
import numpy as np

s = np.array([np.datetime64(f"2025-10-{d:02d}") for d in (23, 24, 25)], np.datetime64)
t = np.array([1, 2, 3])
reveal_type(s)
reveal_type(t)
reveal_type(s.__truediv__(t))

s / t
```

### Error message:

```shell
The type revealed of the division operation is `Any`
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

python 3.12
numpy 2.3.4

### Type-checker version and settings:

pyright 1.1.407
mypy 1.18.2

### Additional typing packages.

Note:  This came up with `pandas-stubs`.  

We think the solution is to add an overload that returns `Never` .

issues.title: SIMD: unify SIMD kernel selection across NumPy and OpenBLAS/MKL
issues.body:
It might make sense to unify the selection of SIMD kernels used in both ufuncs (via our dispatching) and linalg (by third-party BLAS implementations). We use [runtime settings](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/simd/build-options.html#runtime-dispatch) of `NPY_DISABLE_CPU_FEATURES` and `NPY_ENABLE_CPU_FEATURES`, OpenBLAS uses `OPENBLAS_CORETYPE`, I don't see [how MKL lets users](https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/docs/onemkl/developer-guide-windows/2025-2/managing-behavior-of-onemkl-with-env-vars.html) control the kernels used.

The use of environment variables makes sense since NumPy's dispatch is fixed at import time: function slots are set up to point to the appropriate kernels. So this could not be done via a context manager around the ufunc/linalg function call. But we could try to translate the feature use to OpenBLAS coretype before importing scipy_openblas at startup, or (going the other direction), layer `OPENBLAS_CORETYPE` on top of the NumPy feature selection logic.

BUG: C code generated by f2py is not C23 compliant
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Looks like the C code generated by f2py is not C23 compliant and fails to compile with gcc 15.

For instance, this can be seen trying to build scikits.odes-daepack on rolling linux distros that are already at gcc 15. Editing the `meson.build` file to include a 'c_std=c17' seems to fix the issue.

The problem seems to be triggered when generating functions that take a function as a parameter. The latter gets in the signature as `f2py_func()` that is a function taking an arbitrary number of parameters in C<23 but is not the same in C23 that wants a full signature.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
`uv add scikits.odes` on a system with gcc 15.
```

### Error message:

```shell
N/A
```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

python 3.13.9
numpy 2.3.4

### Runtime Environment:

N/A

### Context for the issue:

Not necessarily a problem, if properly documented.

issues.title: TYP: invalid default value documented on `array`'s `ndmax` parameter
issues.body:
### Describe the issue:

Hello from downstream, @jorenham !

first of: we also have a couple inspect-based tests in astropy intended to catch discrepancies between numpy signatures and our NEP 18 dispatch functions. Functions which didn't have signatures available at runtime were simply ignored, but your recent work has allowed finding many more issues with our NEP 18 implementations, so thanks a lot for that !

I'm seeing a small issue with gh-30138 though; `None` doesn't appear to be a valid value for `array`'s `ndmax` argument at runtime (an integer is expected). Instead, and based on my understanding of gh-29569, it seems the default value should actually be `0`.
It can be worked around in astropy alright, but it feels slightly off that I need to both re-expose the default value as `None` (granted, this part is imposed by *our* tests) *and* include logic in the implementation to handle this special case. It's also a bit awkward that the parameter is typed as `int` but uses `None` as a default.

### Reproduce the code example:

```python
# a script will not cut it
```

### Error message:

```shell

```

### Python and NumPy Versions:

Python 3.11.18 (irrelevant)
numpy 2.4.0dev (d8e1c8ce6f0bd7c2dda825f88eb61e02525829ed)

not actually detected at typecheck-time

commit.message:
ENH: Run SWIG unit tests in CI action (#30161)

* Replace deprecated unittest.makeSuite() by unittest.TestLoader().loadTestsFromTestCase()

* Do not use negative values in argument of Tensor.<type>Max()

The unit tests involving `<type>TestCase.testMaxWrongDim` do not work for
`<type>` being one of `uchar`, `ushort`, `uint`, `ulong`, and
`ulongLong` (which translate to `uint8`, `uint16`, `uint32`, `uint64`, and
`uint64`, respectively). Instead of raising the expected `TypeError`, the
unit tests raise `OverflowError`, with the error message “Python integer -1
out of bounds for <type>”. This is fixed by replacing the negative values
in the argument of the `max` function by positive ones.

* Run unit tests for the SWIG binding at the end of the sdist job

The unit tests will be run in the Linux workflow using the Makefile
distributed in `tools/swig/test` directory. They are run after installation
of NumPy in the system, ensuring that the C header files are correctly
included (see GitHub issue [#30131](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/30131)).

issues.title: RFC: Should we remove the 'good first issue' label?
issues.body:
Related to other discussions on low effort PRs #31679 and #32207

Should we remove the 'good first issue' label?

Note that we mention this label in the "[Issues for new contributors](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/21355)" section of the docs. It is also mentioned briefly at the end of the "[A typical workflow for triaging issues](https://scikit-learn.org/dev/developers/bug_triaging.html#a-typical-workflow-for-triaging-issues)" section.

Reasons for:

* currently there are no open issues with this label (https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aopen%20label%3A%22good%20first%20issue%22)
* it is rare for good first issues to occur naturally. Often it requires maintainers specifically trying to think of one and spending time writing thorough details and guidance in an issue, probably what happens when searching for issues for people to work on in sprints, and even then, during the sprint, guidance is often required.
* it often attracts *many* low quality PRs - this is possibly because it's aggregated on sites such as https://goodfirstissue.dev/. It's difficult to find examples as we often remove the label but maybe #31318 and #30352 are examples of how much interest the label often attracts.
* it may be better for a user to start work on something that they use themselves and are familiar with, or something they already have background knowledge of. This would of course vary between people, making it a difficult label to use.
   * related, as described in @betatim's [post](https://discuss.scientific-python.org/t/what-does-it-mean-to-be-a-project-that-is-welcoming-to-newcomers/2127/3) on scientific-python, the type of users attracted to this label may be simply interested in getting a PR merged in a 'big' project. From Ralf: 'Promising new contributors are almost always motivated by a problem/topic, not by “getting on the scoreboard”'  
* for reference NumPy does not have a good first issue label (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/21355) they do have a 'sprintable' label

This is just a request for comment, I understand if we decide to keep this label in the end.

cc @scikit-learn/core-devs

issues.title: Feature Request: Add explained variance ratios for X and Y to `PLSRegression`

labels.name: Needs Triage
labels.description: Issue requires triage

issues.body:
### Describe the workflow you want to enable

Currently, `sklearn.cross_decomposition.PLSRegression` does not expose any measure of explained variance for either the predictor (`X`) or response (`Y`) spaces.

In different disciplines (such as multivartiate statistical process control, -omic sciences or chemometrics), the explained variance in `X` and `Y` spaces is a core interpretability metric and is routinely used to interpret PLS models — analogous to how PCA exposes `explained_variance_ratio_`. Not having access to it in the `PLSRegression` makes it difficult to:

- Quantify how much variance each latent variable captures,

- Compare models with different numbers of components, and

- Produce diagnostic or variance-explained plots (as is standard in different disciplines where latent space interpretability is important).


### Describe your proposed solution

#### Proposed solution

I propose adding two new attributes, automatically computed after fitting:

- `explained_x_variance_ratio_ `: `ndarray` of shape (`n_components`)
    Fraction of variance explained in X-space for each component.

- `explained_y_variance_ratio_ `: `ndarray` of shape (`n_components`)
    Fraction of variance explained in Y-space for each component.


These values are derived using standard PLS sequential deflation methodology (see Wegelin, 2000; Abdi, 2003), where variance explained = reduction in total variance after deflation per component, where each matrix is asymmetrically deflated per each component as follows:

$$X←X - \hat{X}_a = X - t_ap_a^T$$

$$Y←Y - \hat{Y}_a = Y - t_aq_a^T$$

This mirrors the `PCA` API (`explained_variance_ratio_`) and significantly improves usability for diagnostics and visualization.

#### Implementation sketch

```python
class PLSRegression(_PLS):
""" Documentation updated to include the follwoing attributes:

    Attributes
    ----------
    explained_x_variance_ratio_ : ndarray of shape (n_components,)
        Explained variance ratio in X-space (predictors) for each component.
        This measures how much variance in the predictor variables each latent
        variable captures. Calculated in fit().

    explained_y_variance_ratio_ : ndarray of shape (n_components,)
        Explained variance ratio in Y-space (response) for each component.
        This measures how much variance in the response
        each latent variable explains. Calculated in fit().
"""

    def __init__(self, ...):
        [this section is not modified]

    def fit(self, X, y):
        super().fit(X, y)
        # Calculate explained variance ratios
        (
            self.explained_x_variance_ratio_,
            self.explained_y_variance_ratio_,
        ) = self._calculate_explained_variance(X, y)

        return self

    def _calculate_explained_variance(
        self, X, y
    ) -> tuple[np.ndarray, np.ndarray]:
        """Calculate explained variance ratios using sequential deflation.

        This implements the variance decomposition for PLS regression following
        the deflation methodology described in Wegelin (2000).

        This method calculates how much variance each component explains by
        sequentially deflating the X and Y matrices. This is the standard
        approach in PLS and provides accurate component-wise variance.

        Parameters
        ----------
        X : array-like of shape (n_samples, n_features)
            Training vectors. Accepts numpy arrays, pandas DataFrames.
        y : array-like of shape (n_samples,) or (n_samples, n_targets)
            Target vectors. Accepts 1D (univariate) or 2D (multivariate) targets.

        Returns
        -------
        tuple[ndarray, ndarray]
            - X variance ratios of shape (n_components,)
            - Y variance ratios of shape (n_components,)
        """
        # Convert to arrays and ensure y is 2D (handles pandas DataFrame/Series)
        X = np.asarray(X, dtype=float)
        y_array = np.asarray(y, dtype=float)
        y = np.atleast_2d(y_array).T if y_array.ndim == 1 else y_array

        # Center X and Y (PLS already centers data, but we need the original centered versions)
        X_centered = X - X.mean(axis=0)
        y_centered = y - y.mean(axis=0)

        # Check for scaling
        if self.scale:
            # Scale to unit variance, avoiding division by zero
            X_centered /= np.maximum(X.std(axis=0, ddof=1), 1.0)
            y_centered /= np.maximum(y.std(axis=0, ddof=1), 1.0)

        # Total variance in centered data
        X_total_var = np.var(X_centered, axis=0).sum()
        y_total_var = np.var(y_centered, axis=0).sum()

        # Initialize matrices for deflation
        X_current = X_centered.copy()
        y_current = y_centered.copy()

        X_var_ratios = []
        y_var_ratios = []

        # For each component, calculate variance explained then deflate
        for a in range(self.n_components):
            # Get scores and loadings for component a (using slicing to keep 2D)
            t_a = self.x_scores_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_samples, 1)
            p_a = self.x_loadings_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_features_X, 1)
            q_a = self.y_loadings_[:, a:a+1]  # (n_features_y, 1)

            # Reconstruct X and y using current component
            X_hat = t_a @ p_a.T
            y_hat = t_a @ q_a.T

            # Variance of current residual before deflation
            X_var_before = np.var(X_current, axis=0).sum()
            y_var_before = np.var(y_current, axis=0).sum()

            # Deflate X and y
            X_current -= X_hat
            y_current -= y_hat

            # Variance of residual after deflation
            X_var_after = np.var(X_current, axis=0).sum()
            y_var_after = np.var(y_current, axis=0).sum()

            # Store variance explained as ratio of total variance
            X_var_ratios.append((X_var_before - X_var_after) / X_total_var)
            y_var_ratios.append((y_var_before - y_var_after) / y_total_var)

        return np.array(X_var_ratios), np.array(y_var_ratios)
```

#### Usage Example

```python
pls = PLSRegression().fit(X, y)
explained_x_variance = pls.explained_x_variance_ratio_
explained_y_variance = pls.explained_y_variance_ratio_
```

#### Testing

I have tested that this implementation provides the same results as the ones described by:

Abdi, H. (2003). Partial Least Squares (PLS) Regression. In Lewis-Beck M., Bryman A., Futing T. (Eds.), Encyclopedia of Social Sciences Research Methods. Thousand Oaks (CA): Sage.

I have also tested that this implementation does not break the `scikit-learn` estimator API:

```python
# Test compliance with scikit-learn
def test_compliance_pls_regression():
    # Arrange
    transformer = PLSRegression()
    # Act & Assert
    check_estimator(transformer)
```

### Next steps

If maintainers agree this feature fits within scope, I would be happy to:

- Open a PR adding the attributes to PLSRegression,

- Include updated documentation and examples, and

- Add unit tests verifying correctness against synthetic datasets and published examples.


### Describe alternatives you've considered, if relevant

_No response_

### Additional context

- No changes to existing API or behavior.
- Attributes are only added post-fit (similar to PCA’s `explained_variance_ratio_`).
- Could be extended to other PLS methods *(e.g., `PLSCanonical`) but it requires that other methods expose the `x_scores_` and the `y_scores_` (currently are not exposed) and to symmetrically  deflate the `Y` matrix.

### Previous issues

This request is not new, there were some previous. issues:

- https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/19896  (open but no  complete implementation suggested)
- https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/30470 (closed)

issues.title: StandardScaler raises unclear error with empty feature names

labels.name: Needs Reproducible Code
labels.description: Issue requires reproducible code

issues.body:
### Describe the bug

When using StandardScaler with a pandas DataFrame that has empty strings as feature names (which can happen with certain data processing pipelines), the scaler raises a confusing error message that doesn't clearly indicate the root cause of the problem.

The error message should be more descriptive and guide users to fix the issue with their feature names.

### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```py
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

# Create DataFrame with empty string as column name
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10, 3), columns=['feature1', '', 'feature3'])

# Try to fit StandardScaler
scaler = StandardScaler()
scaler.fit(df)  # This raises an unclear error
```

### Expected Results

Either:
1. StandardScaler should raise a clear, informative error message like: "Feature names must be non-empty strings. Found empty string in column 1."
2. Or it should work by automatically handling empty feature names
3. Or raise a ValueError with a helpful message during validation

### Actual Results

KeyError: ''

The error message is not informative about what went wrong. It just shows that an empty string key was not found, without explaining that empty feature names are problematic.

### Versions

```shell
scikit-learn: 1.5.2
pandas: 2.2.0
numpy: 1.26.4
Python: 3.11.5
```

issues.title: DOC Create triage guide in maintainer documentation
issues.body:
As part of talking about triaging at the Scientific Python Summit I realised that we have quite some cumulative experience with triaging. There are also different approaches to things.

As a result I think it would be useful if we create a triaging guide as part of our developer/maintainer documentation. The goal of the guide would be to serve as a reference for what to do as a triager, what tools we have available to help with the process and so on.

Some initial things I can think of including:
* list of labels we have for triaging and what to use them for
* "please don't open a PR before the discussion has converged" as a policy (triagers should close these "early PRs" to help enforce this)
* bookmarked search queries/lists of issues
  * [needs triage](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc%20is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22Needs%20Triage%22)
  * [new PR without reviews](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+review%3Anone+sort%3Acreated-desc)
  * [new PR without reviews by a maintainer](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Ascikit-learn%2Fscikit-learn+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+author%3Abetatim+author%3Aogrisel+author%3Aglemaitre+author%3Alesteve+review%3Anone&type=pullrequests&s=created&o=desc)
     * needs more maintainer usernames in the query
     * we could have a similar query for recurring contributors, but how?
  * [PRs waiting for second reviewer](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+review%3Anone+label%3A%22Waiting+for+Second+Reviewer%22)
  * [Open PRs that you have reviewed in the past](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pulls?q=sort%3Aupdated-desc+is%3Apr+is%3Aopen+reviewed-by%3A%40me+)

Can you think of more search queries that would be useful @lesteve?



xref https://github.com/scientific-python/summit-2025-nov/issues/6

issues.title: Reduce “Can I take this?” by front-loading /take rule
issues.body: ## Summary New contributors frequently comment “Can I take this?” on issues without the *help wanted* label. This creates notification noise and does not trigger CI assignment. The current contributing docs lead with “apply the ‘help wanted’ label to find issues… then comment `/take`”, which is easy to mislead as “`/take` is only for ‘help wanted’ issues”. ## evidence - **Maintainers have posted warnings like “comments such as ‘can I work on this’ or ‘assign this to me’ may get you banned” on issues already being worked on.** - **Recent examples of “Can I take this?” / “assign this to me” appear across issues.** (*The following images are only used to demonstrate the existence of this situation and have no other meaning.*) - **This noise hides actionable updates and shifts cognitive load to maintainers.** ## cause - The contribution guidelines are lengthy and detailed, which may make it difficult for beginners to quickly grasp the key points. If the opening example emphasizes a certain label, it can easily be misunderstood as "this is the only situation that can be done".In Contributing Doc,it emphasizes “help wanted” as the easy way to find issues and then says to comment `/take`. For some new contributer and skimmers, the mental model becomes: ***help wanted → allowed to /take; everything else → ask first***. - Many newcomers, out of politeness or lack of confidence, will first ask, "Can I do this?" to avoid doing something pointless or infringing on others' territory. This reflects their uncertainty about community norms. - The doc later explains time windows, stale/claimed PRs, etc., but many newcomers never read that. - Placing “filter by *help wanted* … then comment `/take`” early in the doc can plausibly mislead newcomers due to well-documented effects: [**Serial-position effect**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial-position_effect?) makes early information disproportionately influential, so readers treat it as the operative rule;and the [**Web User Behaviour Directed by Information Scent**](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/web-user-behaviour-directed-by-information-scent?) and the [**Default Effect**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Default_effect?) shows people often follow an implied “recommended” option when uncertain. Taken together, these explain why newcomers may ask “Can I take this?” on non-labelled issues. ## Proposal 1. **Front-load the universal rule right in the note box:** - “`/take` works for any unclaimed issue; the ‘help wanted’ label is only a discovery aid.” 2. **Add a one-sentence callout to discourage noise:** - “Please avoid comments like ‘Can I take this?’—use '`/take` instead. If you need design feedback, briefly outline your plan and then `/take`.” 3. **Link “how to check if an issue is already taken / time windows” from that same box.** ## Why do this? - This does not change policy; it clarifies and surfaces the existing policy. - No restructuring of the entire page—just a small copy edit and one cross-link. - Reduce the noise.

issues.title: Liveness / Readiness / Startup probe path for Airflow 3.x

labels.name: kind:bug
labels.description: This is a clearly a bug

labels.name: area:helm-chart
labels.description: Airflow Helm Chart

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: label for new issues that we didn't triage yet

issues.body:
### Official Helm Chart version

1.18.0 (latest released)

### Apache Airflow version

3.0.2

### Kubernetes Version

1.31.8

### Helm Chart configuration

```bash
webserver:
  enabled: true
  # Add custom annotations to the webserver configmap
  configMapAnnotations: {}
  #  hostAliases for the webserver pod
  hostAliases: []
  #  - ip: "127.0.0.1"
  #    hostnames:
  #      - "foo.local"
  #  - ip: "10.1.2.3"
  #    hostnames:
  #      - "foo.remote"
  allowPodLogReading: true
  livenessProbe:
    initialDelaySeconds: 15
    timeoutSeconds: 5
    failureThreshold: 5
    periodSeconds: 10
    scheme: HTTP

  readinessProbe:
    initialDelaySeconds: 15
    timeoutSeconds: 5
    failureThreshold: 5
    periodSeconds: 10
    scheme: HTTP

  # Wait for at most 1 minute (6*10s) for the webserver container to startup.
  # livenessProbe kicks in after the first successful startupProbe
  startupProbe:
    initialDelaySeconds: 0
    timeoutSeconds: 20
    failureThreshold: 6
    periodSeconds: 10
    scheme: HTTP
```

### Docker Image customizations

```bash
Added cacerts for handshaking with on-prem servers. 


ADD --chown=root:root --chmod=0644 ${AIP_CDN_URL}/certificates/xxx.net.crt /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/xxx.crt
ADD --chown=root:root --chmod=0644 ${AIP_CDN_URL}/certificates/yyy.crt /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/yyy.crt
ADD --chown=root:root --chmod=0644 ${AIP_CDN_URL}/certificates/zzz.crt /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/zzz.crt

RUN update-ca-certificates \
  && cat /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/xxx.crt >> $(python -m certifi) \
  && cat /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/yyy.crt >> $(python -m certifi) \
  && cat /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/zzz.crt >> $(python -m certifi) \
  && chown airflow:root ${PYTHON_DIR}/site-packages/certifi/cacert.pem
```

### What happened

```bash
The webserver container does not change to a ready state.


$ k get po  | grep webserver
aip-sandbox-airflow-webserver-5976bdd9b5-bf5sx     1/1     Running            0          104m
aip-sandbox-airflow-webserver-6d9cc87d65-vhscs     0/1     Running            0          80s



$ k logs aip-sandbox-airflow-webserver-6d9cc87d65-vhscs -f

/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/airflow/api_fastapi/auth/tokens.py:522 DeprecationWarning: The secret_key option in [webserver] has been moved to the secret_key option in [api] - the old setting has been used, but please update your config.
INFO:     Started server process [12]
INFO:     Waiting for application startup.
INFO:     Application startup complete.
INFO:     172.16.62.195:33074 - "GET /health HTTP/1.1" 404 Not Found
INFO:     172.16.62.195:57566 - "GET /health HTTP/1.1" 404 Not Found
```

### What you think should happen instead

It seems that the three paths need to be changed to '/api/v2/monitor/health' or 
The three probe paths need to be changed to '/api/v2/monitor/health' or be configurable via Helm values.


[Airflow 3.12.0 Checking Airflow Health Status](https://airflow.apache.org/docs/apache-airflow/stable/administration-and-deployment/logging-monitoring/check-health.html#checking-airflow-health-status)

### How to reproduce

Deploy helm chart for Airflow 3.X. 

### Anything else

_No response_

issues.title: FAB Create Token API fails with "Working outside of application context" after PR #57815

labels.name: kind:bug
labels.description: This is a clearly a bug

labels.name: area:API
labels.description: Airflow's REST/HTTP API

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: label for new issues that we didn't triage yet

issues.body:
### Apache Airflow version

main (development)

### If "Other Airflow 2/3 version" selected, which one?

_No response_

### What happened?

After updating to a build of Airflow that includes PR #57815, the FAB auth manager endpoint `/auth/token` started failing with a 500 error and the following exception in the API server logs:
```
RuntimeError: Working outside of application context.
...
File ".../airflow/providers/fab/auth_manager/security_manager/override.py", line XXX, in auth_type
    return current_app.config["AUTH_TYPE"]
```
The call stack shows this originates from `FABAuthManagerLogin.create_token(...)`, which reads `auth_manager.security_manager.auth_type`, and that `auth_type` property is implemented as `return current_app.config["AUTH_TYPE"]` in `FabAirflowSecurityManagerOverride`.

In PR #57815, the FastAPI routes in `providers/fab/src/airflow/providers/fab/auth_manager/api_fastapi/routes/login.py` were changed: the `create_token`, `create_token_cli`, and `logout` endpoints no longer wrap their logic in with `get_application_builder(): ...`. Instead, they now call `FABAuthManagerLogin.create_token(...)` (or `get_auth_manager().get_url_login()`) directly, without setting up a Flask app context.

As a result, when these endpoints are hit via the API server, `current_app` is not bound and any access to `current_app.config["AUTH_TYPE"]` (and similar properties) fails with `RuntimeError: Working outside of application context.`

### What you think should happen instead?

_No response_

### How to reproduce

```bash
breeze start-airflow
```

```bash
curl --location 'http://localhost:28080/auth/token' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--data '{"username":"admin","password":"admin"}'
```

### Operating System

macOS 15.5

### Versions of Apache Airflow Providers

_No response_

### Deployment

Other

### Deployment details

Deployment: Breeze local dev environment (Docker Compose, airflow api-server with uvicorn)

### Anything else?

_No response_

issues.body:
### Apache Airflow version

Other Airflow 2/3 version (please specify below)

### If "Other Airflow 2/3 version" selected, which one?

3.1.1

### What happened?

When using `TriggerDagRunOperator`, `airflow.exceptions.ParamValidationError` are not being shown in the triggerer log. 
In the triggerer (task) log, this is what we see:
```
AirflowRuntimeError: API_SERVER_ERROR: {'status_code': 500, 'message': 'Server returned error', 'detail': {'message': 'Internal server error', 'correlation-id': '...'}}
```

The true error is only unveiled when we dig into the api-server logs.

### What you think should happen instead?

`airflow.exceptions.ParamValidationError` should show up in the log of `TriggerDagRunOperator` tasks.

### How to reproduce

1. Build a DAG `underlying_dag` that takes certain Params, e.g. `"test_param": Param("", type="string", enum=["a", "b"]),`
2. use TriggerDagRunOperator in a trigger DAG `trigger_dag`
3. call the TriggerDagRunOperator with an invalid parameter, e.g. 
```
TriggerDagRunOperator.partial(task_id="trigger_dag", trigger_dag_id="underlying_dag").expand(
    conf=[{"test_param": "d"}]
)
```
4. observe that the task fails and the logging described above.
5. observe the ParamValidationError in api-server

issues.title: AssetAliases are not shown in assets tab

labels.name: kind:bug
labels.description: This is a clearly a bug

labels.name: area:UI
labels.description: Related to UI/UX. For Frontend Developers.

labels.name: needs-triage
labels.description: label for new issues that we didn't triage yet

issues.body:
### Apache Airflow version

3.1.2

### If "Other Airflow 2/3 version" selected, which one?

_No response_

### What happened?

When using DAGs that attach AssetAliases to outlets, the concrete asset is created by the producing task. AssetAliases associated to these dynamically created assets do not appear in the Assets tab of the UI, even when assets are attached via Metadata. The following example code demonstrates the issue:

```python
from datetime import UTC, datetime
from airflow.providers.standard.operators.python import PythonOperator
from airflow.sdk import Asset, AssetAlias, Metadata, dag, task

first_alias = AssetAlias(name='a.first.data.alias',)
second_alias = AssetAlias(name='a.second.data.alias',)

@dag(schedule=None,tags=['test'],)
def test_alias_producer_dag():
    def produce_asset():
        yield Metadata(Asset(name='a.first.data.asset', uri='s3://bucket/mydata.csv', extra={'path': '/some/local/path.txt'},), {'timestamp': datetime.now(tz=UTC).isoformat()}, first_alias,)
    PythonOperator(task_id='produce_asset', python_callable=produce_asset, outlets=[first_alias],)

@dag(schedule=[first_alias],tags=['test'],)
def test_alias_intermediate_dag():
    @task(inlets=[first_alias], outlets=[second_alias])
    def process_asset(inlet_events: dict[Asset | AssetAlias, list[Metadata]]):
        events: list[Metadata] = inlet_events[first_alias]
        for event in events:
            print(f'Event: {event}')
        yield Metadata(Asset(name='a.second.data.asset', uri='s3://bucket/otherdata.csv', extra={'path': '/some/other/local/path.txt'},), {'timestamp': datetime.now(tz=UTC).isoformat()}, second_alias,)
    process_asset()

@dag(schedule=[second_alias],tags=['test'],)
def test_alias_consumer_dag():
    @task(inlets=[second_alias])
    def consume_asset(inlet_events: dict[Asset | AssetAlias, list[Metadata]]):
        events: list[Metadata] = inlet_events[second_alias]
        for event in events:
            print(f'Event: {event}')
    consume_asset()

test_alias_producer_dag()
test_alias_intermediate_dag()
test_alias_consumer_dag()
```

Observed behavior:
- The dynamically attached Asset is correctly produced.
- The AssetAlias used as outlet and the Assets itself do NOT appear as an asset in the 'Assets' tab at all.
- This seems to affect all dynamically produced assets that use AssetAlias via Metadata.

### What you think should happen instead?

Expectation: The AssetAlias should appear in the assets tab.

### How to reproduce

See example DAG code in previous sections. To reproduce:
1. Define DAG with dynamic assets and attach AssetAlias via Metadata/outlets as in example above
2. Run the DAG; ensure that asset events are produced with AssetAlias and dynamically generated Asset
3. Check the Asset Events are created in the Task view.
4. The attached AssetAlias (e.g. 'a.first.data.alias') does NOT appear in the assets tab.

### Operating System

docker compose

### Versions of Apache Airflow Providers

_No response_

### Deployment

Docker-Compose

### Deployment details

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

### Are you willing to submit PR?

issues.title: [BUG]runner.run_streamed with handoff creates separate traces for chained agents

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

Local machine
### MLflow version
mlflow 3.5.1
### System information
## 🐛 Bug Report: `runner.run_streamed` with `handoff` creates separate traces for chained agents
### 🔍 Summary
When chaining multiple Agents using the OpenAI Agents SDK **`handoff` mechanism** and executing the sequence via **`runner.run_streamed`**, the expected behavior of a single, continuous trace is not achieved. Instead, each Agent in the chain produces a **separate, independent MLflow Trace**, breaking the end-to-end visibility of the agent execution flow.
### 📝 Description
We are utilizing the ` OpenAI Agents SDK ` to build complex workflows where one Agent's output is passed to the next Agent (chained using `handoff`).
When executing this chain using the streaming method, **`runner.run_streamed()`**, the MLflow tracing functionality appears to reset or re-initialize a new run/trace context at the transition point between Agents (i.e., where the `handoff` occurs).
**Expected Behavior:**
The entire sequence of agent calls, from the initial trigger through all subsequent `handoff` steps, should be recorded as a **single, unified MLflow Trace/Run** that captures the entire conversation flow, including intermediate tool calls and final outputs.
**Actual Behavior:**
The execution results in **$N$ distinct MLflow Traces** (where $N$ is the number of agents in the chain). Each trace only captures the activity of the specific Agent responsible for that segment of execution. This makes debugging and analyzing the complete, end-to-end agent logic extremely difficult.
### Describe the problem
Three Agents were connected in series, resulting in three traces


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**:macos
- **Python version**:3.11
- **yarn version, if running the dev UI**:


### Describe the problem

Three Agents were connected in series, resulting in three traces

issues.body: ### Willingness to contribute Yes. I can contribute this feature independently. ### Proposal Summary Currently, when using crews (with flow)/agents/tasks/LLMs following the Crew AI documentation (without creating a subclass), the rendering in mlflow looks like this: Exemple of an agent with a Task ```python @agent def researcher(self) -> Agent: return Agent( config=self.agents_config['researcher'], # type: ignore[index] verbose=True, tools=[SerperDevTool()] ) @task def reporting_task(self) -> Task: return Task( config=self.tasks_config['reporting_task'] # type: ignore[index] ) @crew def crew(self) -> Crew: return Crew( agents=[ self.researcher(), self.reporting_analyst() ], tasks=[ self.reporting_task() ], process=Process.sequential ) ``` The purpose of this feature is to automatically display the following in the UI: - Crew names - Task names - Agent roles - LLM model names ### Motivation > #### What is the use case for this feature? Increase visibility for Crews with many tasks and agents, and Flows in general. Example: Flow => Crew A => If condition is True then Crew B else Crew C. As it is, it's hard to tell which Crew has been launched with the mlflow UI. > #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general? Improve the integration of the CrewAI framework > #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization? I use a lot mlflow to monitor my agent (with CrewAI or DSPY). And this feature would be a real benefit in helping me debug problems. > #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case? In my opinion, it's not difficult to achieve. ### Details Here an exemple of the result with this feature : ### What machine learning domain(s) is this feature request about? - [ ] `domain/genai`: LLMs, Agents, and other GenAI-related use cases - [ ] `domain/classical-ml`: Traditional machine learning, such as linear regression. - [ ] `domain/deep-learning`: Deep learning and neural networks. - [x] `domain/platform`: MLflow platform foundation, not specific to a particular machine learning domain. ### What area(s) of MLflow is this feature request about? - [ ] `area/tracking`: Tracking Service, tracking client APIs, autologging - [ ] `area/model-registry`: Model Registry service, APIs, and the fluent client calls for Model Registry - [ ] `area/scoring`: MLflow model serving, deployment tools, Spark UDFs - [ ] `area/evaluation`: MLflow model evaluation features, evaluation metrics, and evaluation workflows - [ ] `area/prompt`: MLflow prompt engineering features, prompt templates, and prompt management - [x] `area/tracing`: MLflow Tracing features, tracing APIs, and LLM tracing functionality - [ ] `area/gateway`: MLflow AI Gateway client APIs, server, and third-party integrations - [ ] `area/projects`: MLproject format, project running backends - [ ] `area/uiux`: Front-end, user experience, plotting - [ ] `area/docs`: MLflow documentation pages

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

No. I cannot contribute this feature at this time.

### Proposal Summary

I propose adding webhook functionality for key events originating from MLflow Tracing. For example, this would allow sending real-time notifications to a specified URL when a code error is detected during a trace execution or when the latency of a specific trace exceeds a configured threshold. This would enable proactive monitoring and rapid response to the state of Agent applications.

### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?
By adding real-time, webhook-based notification capabilities, users can immediately recognize and respond to issues without having to periodically check the MLflow UI. This would be a great help in reducing issue response times.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
An automated monitoring and notification system is essential for reliable Agent service operations. This would minimize service downtime and maximize operational efficiency.

issues.title: [FR] Serialization parity between `local` and `virtualenv` values for `env_manager` in spark_udf

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: area/scoring
labels.description: MLflow Model server, model deployment tools, Spark UDFs

labels.name: domain/deep-learning
labels.description: Feature requests for Deep Learning use cases

labels.name: domain/classical-ml
labels.description: Feature requests for Classical ML use cases

labels.name: domain/platform
labels.description: Feature requests about platform foundation, not specific to a problem domain

issues.body:
### Willingness to contribute

Yes. I would be willing to contribute this feature with guidance from the MLflow community.

### Proposal Summary

The `mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf` high level API has different I/O limitations depending on the `env_manager` parameter used (`"local"` vs `"virtualenv"`). Since one dimension here is a modeling choice and the other is an operational choice, we should remove this coupling and provide consistent I/O parity between the two env manager settings.

### Motivation

> #### What is the use case for this feature?
Models that include input data types that are not JSON serializable but are pyarrow serializable fail to predict if loaded into a `spark_udf` with `env_manager = "virtualenv"`, while they do work with `env_manager="local"`. Conversely, if something is JSON serializable but not pyarrow serializable, it will work only with `env_manager = "virtualenv"` and not `env_manager="local"`

This argues for one of two feature approaches:
1. Adopt a body of type regressions against the JSON serialization powering the scoring server, to ensure parity with pyarrow (which is the usual serialization pattern supported in spark)
2. [Preferred, but probably harder] adjust the communication to the Scoring Server to leverage Arrow Flight RPC over JSON RESTful interface. This would delegate parity to the arrow project, and likely also result in increased performance of the scoring server.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for MLflow users in general?
Standard spark communication with executors is driven through pyarrow, while communication to the scoring server is through JSON request payload. This causes a lack of parity in model compatibility for `mlflow.pyfunc.spark_udf()` calls when input data is serializable into pyarrow and not json, or vice versa. In addition, if there are differences in the serialization framework (for instance, the treatment of nulls) this can lead to model output changes that result from a strictly operational refactor.

This can be for quite common datatypes; an example of one that works with `env_manager="local"` but not `env_manager = "virtualenv"` is the python base `binary` type, which may for instance be used to represent image media loaded from external storage.

> #### Why is this use case valuable to support for your project(s) or organization?

We have strict policies around copying media outside of governed s3 buckets, and so need to persist a copy in memory to avoid an expensive i/o operation on a GPU executor. Simultaneously, we value the strict environment guarantees provided by `env_manager = "virtualenv"`.

> #### Why is it currently difficult to achieve this use case?

You cannot currently encapsulate models leveraging binary type data using the `virtualenv` eng

### Details

_No response_

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: area/uiux
labels.description: Front-end, user experience, plotting, JavaScript, JavaScript dev server

issues.body: ### MLflow version 3.5.1 ### System information - **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: OS X Tahoe 26.0.1 - **Python version**: 3.11.7 - **yarn version, if running the dev UI**: 4.9.1 (built the UI via `yarn build`) ### Describe the problem Cannot remove tags that were assigned to a trace from the UI. Removing from Python seems to be working, because there it's still using the old v2 endpoint. The stack trace from the server is the following: ``` 2025/11/06 18:13:29 ERROR mlflow.server: Exception on /ajax-api/3.0/mlflow/traces/tr-5cdb4c1edfaec66546907c1c95c3bbcd/tags [DELETE] Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1511, in wsgi_app response = self.full_dispatch_request() File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 919, in full_dispatch_request rv = self.handle_user_exception(e) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask_cors/extension.py", line 176, in wrapped_function return cors_after_request(app.make_response(f(*args, **kwargs))) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 917, in full_dispatch_request rv = self.dispatch_request() File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 902, in dispatch_request return self.ensure_sync(self.view_functions[rule.endpoint])(**view_args) # type: ignore[no-any-return] File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 715, in wrapper return func(*args, **kwargs) File "/Users/kirill/mlflow/mlflow/server/handlers.py", line 756, in wrapper return func(*args, **kwargs) TypeError: _delete_trace_tag() got an unexpected keyword argument 'trace_id' ``` I have noticed that the protobuf definition changed between V2 and V3, where V3 has `request_id` instead of `trace_id`. I have tried to make a duplicate of the `mlflow.server.handlers._delete_trace_tag` function with a different name of the argument, which got me to step inside of the function, however, after that I got problems with handling the `key` argument. I assume this is happening because `mlflow.server.handlers._get_request_message` cannot handle this particular request and throws that it doesn't see the `key` argument. Assume this is because this request is different from usual: - DELETE request - No body - Argument is in the query parameter This was as far as I went before it started feeling to me like this is too big for me to dig into myself. ### Steps to reproduce the bug 1) Create a trace and add a span to it 2) Navigate to the trace in the UI 3) Check the tickbox near the trace 4) Open the "Actions" dropdown -> Edit Tags 5) Click on the x near `foo: bar` tag 6) Click on the "Save tags" button to save changes Expected: The selected tag gets deleted Actual: Tag doesn't get deleted ### Code to generate data required to reproduce the bug While running an mlflow server locally: ```python import mlflow mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://localhost:5000") with mlflow.start_run(): with mlflow.start_span("foo") as sp: print("bar") cl = mlflow.client.MlflowClient() cl.set_trace_tag(sp.request_id, "foo", "bar") ``` ### Is the console panel in DevTools showing errors relevant to the bug? ### Does the network panel in DevTools contain failed requests relevant to the bug? ``` DELETE http://localhost:5000/ajax-api/3.0/mlflow/traces/tr-5cdb4c1edfaec66546907c1c95c3bbcd/tags?key=foo Status Code: 500 ```

issues.body:
### Issues Policy acknowledgement

- [x] I have read and agree to submit bug reports in accordance with the [issues policy](https://www.github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/ISSUE_POLICY.md)

### Where did you encounter this bug?

Local machine

### MLflow version

- Client: 3.5.1
- Tracking server: 3.5.1


### System information

- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**: Windows 10
- **Python version**: 3.13.5


### Describe the problem

The llamaindex tracer expects all the LLMs from Llamaindex to return token usage in the `additional_kwargs` field. 
However, not all LLM return these information like the Llamaindex's `OpenAI` class. This causes a KeyError exception that prevents traces data to be logged in async code.

The UI then shows `No trace data available` when attempting to see detailed trace view.

```python
mlflow.llama_index.autolog()

@mlflow.trace
async def call_llm(message: str) -> str:
    llm = GoogleGenAI(model="gemini-2.5-flash-lite", api_key="AIzaSyCntCJ5Xbtrl48Gd4RXCYf0zpcZjuR9F98")
    response = await llm.achat(
        messages=[ChatMessage(role="user", content=message)]
    )
    return str(response)

asyncio.run(call_llm("What is the capital of France?"))
```

commit.message:
